title: How Do I Know If My Child Is Learning Soroban Correctly?
description: You're not a soroban expert, so how can you tell if your child is on the right track? Here are the signs to look for.
imageAlt: Child practicing soroban with parent observing

content.intro: I don't know soroban myself, so how do I know if my daughter is actually learning correctly? After months of worry and research, I've identified the signs that matter – and the ones that don't.

sections.text: Signs Your Child Is On the Right Track

items: ✅ **Accuracy is high:** Getting most answers correct (80%+)
✅ **Speed is improving:** Same problems faster over time
✅ **Can explain their thinking:** "I added 5 and subtracted 2"
✅ **Handles harder problems:** Gradually taking on more difficult challenges
✅ **Uses mental math sometimes:** Starting to visualize without the physical soroban
⚠️ **Accuracy below 50%:** May need to go back to easier levels
⚠️ **No progress for 4+ weeks:** Could be stuck or misunderstanding something
⚠️ **Frustrated crying regularly:** Might be pushed too hard
⚠️ **Guessing instead of calculating:** Not using the method properly
⚠️ **Can't do old problems:** Forgetting earlier skills

sections.text: The app tracks accuracy and progress automatically. Check the stats weekly to see trends, not daily fluctuations.
These are rough guidelines. Every child progresses differently. Consistency matters more than speed.
How to Check Without Knowing Soroban

items: **Watch the app stats:** Accuracy %, problems completed, streaks
**Random mental math quizzes:** "What's 14 + 7?" See how they answer
**Ask them to teach you:** If they can explain, they understand
**Compare to their old videos:** Record them now, compare in 3 months
❌ **Comparison to other kids:** Everyone learns differently
❌ **Not being fastest:** Speed comes later, accuracy first
❌ **Using fingers sometimes:** It's fine while learning

sections.text: If your child is practicing regularly, getting most answers right, and not hating it – they're doing fine. Don't overthink it.

faq.question: Should I learn soroban myself to help?
faq.answer: Helpful but not required. You can encourage, monitor progress, and celebrate wins without knowing the technique yourself.

faq.question: What if the app says they're progressing but I don't see changes?
faq.answer: Mental math improvement is subtle. Give it 3+ months before expecting obvious real-world differences.

faq.question: My child's accuracy dropped suddenly. Should I worry?
faq.answer: Check if they moved to harder problems (normal drop), are distracted, or rushing. One bad week isn't a concern – sustained drops are worth investigating.
